reading: Who was the second President of the United States?
writing: Adams was the second President of the United States.

reading: Who was the first President of the United States?
writing: Washington was the first President of the United States.

reading: Who is the Father of Our Country?
writing: Washington is the Father of Our Country.

reading: Which President is on the one dollar bill?
writing: President Washington is on the one dollar bill.

reading: Which President was during the Civil War?
writing: Lincoln was the president during the Civil War.

reading: Who lived first in the United States?
writing: American Indians lived first in the United States.

reading: Where does the President live?
writing: The President lives in the White House.

reading: What is the capital of the United States?
writing: Washington D.C. is the capital of the United States.

reading: Who have the right to vote?
writing: Citizens have the right to vote.

reading: Who can vote?
writing: Citizens can vote.

reading: Who elect Congress?
writing: The citizens elect Congress.

reading: Where does Congress meet?
writing: Congress meets in the Capital in Washington D.C.

reading: When do we vote for the President?
writing: We vote for the President in November.

reading: What are the colors of the flag?
writing: The flag is red, white, and blue.

reading: How many Senators does the Congress have?
writing: The Congress has one hundred Senators.

reading: What state is the largest?
writing: Alaska is the largest state.

reading: What state has the most people?
writing: The state of California has the most people.

reading: Which city has the most people?
writing: New York City has the most people.

reading: Which country is to the north of the United States?
writing: Canada is to the north of the United States.

reading: What country is to the south of the United States?
writing: Mexico is to the south of the United States.

reading: What was the first state of the United States?
writing: Delaware was the first state of the United States.

reading: What did people want from the Great Britain?
writing: The people want to be free.

reading: What freedom do we want to have?
writing: We want to have freedom of speech.

reading: Who have to pay taxes?
writing: We have to pay taxes.

reading: When is the President's Day?
writing: President's Day is in February.

reading: The Memorial Day is in what month?
writing: Memorial Day is in May.

reading: What month is the Flag Day?
writing: Flag Day is in June.

reading: When is the Independence Day?
writing: Independence Day is in July.

reading: In what month is Labor Day?
writing: Labor Day is in September.

reading: What month is Columbus Day?
writing: Columbus Day is in October.

reading: Thanksgiving falls in what month?
writing: Thanksgiving is in November.

reading: The United States has how many states?
writing: The United States has fifty states.

reading: Where is the White House?
writing: The White House is in Washington D.C.
